title: baby names 2019 emily and jack retain top spots
story: Alexandra, Heidi and Hollie were the girls’ names growing most in popularity last yearJack and Emily were the most popular baby names registered last year, according to the Central Statistics Office (CSO). Jack retained the title as the most popular baby boy’s name, a position it has held since 2007, except for 2016 when James claimed the top spot. Jack was followed by James, Noah, Conor and Daniel as the five most popular names for baby boys in 2019. Emily retains the top spot for girls, followed by Grace, Fiadh, Sophie and Hannah in the top five names for baby girls last year. Emily has been the most popular name for baby girls since 2011. Fiadh and Hannah were new entrants to the top five in 2019. Amelia dropped out of the top five last year, having been there since 2015. The latest publication by the CSO is the second year in a row it has recognised the síneadh fada. New entrants into the top 100 names for boys included Odhrán, Eli, Ruairí and Joey while Doireann and Méabh entered the top 100 names for girls. Odhrán was also the boy’s name that increased the most in popularity between 2018 to 2019, moving up from 138th place to 97th. Alexandra, Heidi and Hollie were the girls’ names growing most in popularity last year. Alexandra moved up 25 places and Heidi and Hollie both moved 20 places in the rankings between 2018 and 2019. There was a wider variety in the names registered with girls, with 4,184 girls’ names in 2019 compared with 3,725 for boys. The CSO’s Baby Names of Ireland lets you track how many babies were registered under any given name in Ireland between the years 1964 and 2018.The CSO has also provided a breakdown of the most popular baby names by county for 2019.Rían was the most popular name for baby boys in Cavan, for example, while Jamie was the most popular boy’s name in Donegal. James was the most popular boy’s name in Dublin city and Dún Laoghaire-Rathdown, while Jack was the most popular in Fingal and south Dublin last year. Charlie, Fionn and Thomas were the most popular baby boy’s names in Carlow while Luke was the most popular in Roscommon. Ella was the most popular name for baby girls in Monaghan last year while Caoimhe was the most popular girl’s name in Sligo. Ava was the most popular girl’s name in Clare while Anna was the most popular in Offaly. Sophie was the most popular girl’s name in Fingal and Dún Laoghaire-Rathdown last year, Ellie was the most popular in south Dublin and Emily in Dublin city. The top ten surnames of babies registered in 2019 is also included in the CSO’s publication. Of the 59,795 live births registered in 2019, 20,356 had unrepeated surnames. These unique surnames included some double-barrelled surnames – for example Driscoll-O’Shea. The top three surnames for births registered were Murphy at 683 (1.1 per cent), Kelly at 567 (0.9 per cent) and Ryan at 450 (0.8 per cent).The CSO has published babies’ forenames since 1998 and receives this data from the General Registration Office (GRO).Carol Anne Hennessy, CSO statistician, said some of the less popular names for boys included Teidí, Saul, Dexter and Ruán and for girls’ included Féile, Jorja, Kyrah and Constance.“Back in 1969, John, Patrick, Michael, James and Thomas were the names most favoured by parents of new-born baby boys. There were 209 male new-borns named John in 2019, just over 7 per cent of the number of boys given the name John in 1969,” she said. “Interestingly, not one of the top five names for girls appeared in the top 100 names a half century earlier. Mary, Catherine, Margaret, Ann and Elizabeth were the most popular names for baby daughters in 1969, with 2,182 baby girls named Mary in that year. “In 2019, there were 452 baby girls named Emily, 20.7 per cent of the number of girls given the name Mary in 1969.”Stay on top of the latest news with our Morning Briefing and Lunchtime Latest newsletters

title: coronavirus advice wash your hands and avoid hugging kissing and hand shaking
story: A spectator wears a face mask at the Dubai Duty Free Tennis ATP Championships  in Dubai. Photograph: Ali HaiderEPAWith the coronavirus spreading rapidly across the world and one case now confirmed on the island of Ireland, much of the focus is on how to deal with the illness and care for the sick.But equally important, if not more important, in what is still a containment phase is how to minimise the odds of contracting the virus and stay safe as the illness spreads.The first and best advice is not to panic. Hysteria is a real enemy in a situation like this.“We are actually in a very delicate situation in which the outbreak can go in any direction based on how we handle it,” World Health Organisation head Dr Tedros Ghebreyesus said on Thursday night. “This is not a time for fear. This is a time for taking action to prevent infection and save lives now,” he added.There has been a huge amount of speculation about the illness, much of which is ill-informed or speculative but what we know for certain now is that the Covid-19 coronavirus is new and scientists are assessing how it spreads.We also know that similar viruses tend to spread via cough and sneeze droplets.’Social distancing’That is why so-called “social distancing” will be important in the days ahead. That means you should move at least a metre away from anyone who appears ill if you can. Avoid shaking hands or hugging or kissing people as part of a greeting.There has also been a lot of talk in recent days about face masks and alcohol based hand sanitisers but - by far - the most effective way to protect yourself is by regularly washing your hands.At the risk of stating the obvious, a quick rinse under the tap doesn’t get rid of dangerous germs. Hands need to be vigourously washed with soap and hot water for at least 20 seconds or the length of time it takes to sing the Happy Birthday song twice.Many people don’t dry their hands either which is why it is important to remember that damp actually can help germs to breed and allows them to spread more easily onto whatever you touch next.According to advice from the HSE, in addition to hand-washing people should also use alcohol based hand sanatisers if necessary.It is also important to cover your mouth and nose with a tissue or your sleeve when you cough and sneeze and to put used tissues into a bin and then wash your hands again. People should not touch their eyes, nose or mouth if their hands are not cleanThe HSE advice also reminds people to clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces.With regard to face masks the HSE advice is simple. People who are well or have no symptoms of illness should not use them. “There’s no evidence that using masks is of any benefit if you are not sick,” it says.People who should use face masks if they have or may have coronavirus or if they are in close contact with someone who has or may have coronavirus or if they are are a healthcare worker in close contact with people who have or may have coronavirus.Healthcare workersAccording to the HSE people who work in a healthcare setting can best protect themselves by regularly washing their hands and covering their mouths and noses when coughing and sneezing.Health care professionals dealing with cases or suspected cases of the coronavirus are being advised to wear personal protective equipment which includes a surgical face mask, a face shield or goggles, gloves and a clean, non-sterile, disposable long-sleeved gown. “If this is not available, wear a plastic apron and roll up sleevesIrish people displayed a propensity to stockpile during the two or three days that the beast from the east made its presence felt two years ago.Bread supplies dried up and fresh meat and dairy disappeared from supermarkets as supply chains displayed a worrying fragility.Will something similar happen if panic about the coronavirus mounts? Possibly.Certainly in other locations concerns over shortages have led some people to stockpile and there has been evidence of panic buying.Already in this country all the face masks have disappeared from pharmacies and even hardware shops.“I don’t think it is necessary, and I certainly don’t advise it,” Mark Woolhouse at the University of Edinburgh to New Scientist this week.Food suplyJennifer Nuzzo at Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security in Baltimore, Maryland told the same magazine that people should ensure they have at least three days’ food supply to hand as they are advised to do during hurricanes. “I’m not saying it’s specifically necessary in this case,” she said.Meanwhile virology blogger Ian Mackay recommended slowly building up a “pandemic stash”.Certainly do not stock up on prescription medicines - not only will you almost certainly not need them but you may make it harder for those that do need them to access them. Which takes us back to the start and the best advice which is don’t panic.Stay on top of the latest news with our Morning Briefing and Lunchtime Latest newsletters

title: coronavirus north s health chief confident virus can be contained
story: Minister for Health Simon harris has visited Dublin Airport where he met with HSE staff providing information about the coronavirus to people as they arrive in Ireland. Video: Bryan O'Brien			                                        					North’s chief medical officer Dr Michael McBride speaking at a press conference on Thursday. Photograph: Michael McHughPA WireNorthern Ireland’s chief medical officer has said he is confident health authorities in Northern Ireland will be able to contain the spread of coronavirus. The first case on the island of Ireland was confirmed on Thursday in a woman who had flown to Dublin from northern Italy and then travelled on to Belfast. She followed the advice from the Public Health Agency (PHA) and contacted her GP and then “self-isolated” at home while awaiting the results of tests. The “presumptive positive” result has been sent to laboratories in England for verification. The PHA has said she is receiving “specialist care”. Dr Michael McBride said at a press conference in Belfast on Thursday that a “small number” of those in contact with the patient had been identified as at risk. Speaking on BBC Radio Ulster on Friday, he said he was “confident that the steps that the inidual took upon return to Northern Ireland, based on advice that was relayed, and indeed the prompt and rapid action by PHA colleagues, will ensure that we’re able to contain this,” he said. “What we do not have in Northern Ireland at this point in time, and this is really crucially important, we do not have cases in Northern Ireland that have occurred in Northern Ireland,” he said. “We don’t have community transmission in Northern Ireland.” “Basically speaking, that has enabled the authorities to put in step everything that has been planned and prepared for to limit spread of the virus to the wider community,” he said. On Friday, Dr John Cuddihy, the director of the Health Protection Surveillance Centre, told journalists in Dublin that “each of the stages of this person’s journey have been identified and all relevant contacts in all of those stages of transport have been contacted (and) traced.” People who sat within two rows of the woman on the plane have been contacted. It is not clear whether she travelled from Dublin to Belfast by public transport, but both Iarnród Éireann and Translink have carried out a “sanitising clean” of the Dublin to Belfast Enterprise trains as a “precautionary measure”. A special isolation unit has been established at the Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast. Travellers who have recently returned from high risk areas, including specific parts of northern Italy, should self-isolate at home and contact their GP by phone, the PHA has advised. “Washing your hands regularly will help prevent flu and other viruses spreading,” the PHA said. Anyone who becomes unwell and suspects they may have been exposed to coronavirus should stay at home and phone their GP for advice. title: earth has new mini moon unlikely last long
story: Earth has acquired a mini moon roughly the size of a car, astronomers have said.The object, designated 2020 CD3, was spotted by an observation station in Arizona on February 19.However, analysis of its speed and orbit has led scientists to confirm that it has been orbiting Earth for about three years.It is only the second known asteroid to have been captured into orbit following an object known as 2006 RH120, which circled Earth between September 2006 and June 2007 before heading into outer space.A similar fate is expected to befall the newly-discovered object, which circles Earth in an uneven oval-shaped orbit once every 47 days. Because the trajectory is not stable, 2020 CD3 will eventually be flung away from the planet.The new moon is thought to be between 1.9 and 3.5 metres across.Kacper Wierxchos, a researcher at the NASA-funded Catalina Sky Survey, made the discovery with colleague Theodore Pruyne.He hailed the rare sighting as big news, tweeting: It's a big deal as, out of one million known asteroids, this is just the second asteroid known to orbit Earth.A spokesman for the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory's Minor Planet Center, which collects data on minor planets and asteroids, said: Orbit integrations indicate that this object is temporarily bound to the Earth.No link to a known artificial object has been found. Further observations and dynamical studies are strongly encouraged.The spokesman added: The story of 2006 RH120 is not without controversy, however, as its orbit appears similar to some Apollo-era spent rockets boosters, and therefore some scientists believe it may be an artificial object.”Meanwhile, Tesla CEO Elon Musk said the car-sized object was not the Telsa Roadster he launched into space in 2018, which is now orbiting the Sun. It's not mine, the tech entrepreneur tweeted.More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: every epidemic make mistake time learn
story: It was China&#39s limp response early on that enabled the rampant spread of coronavirus As a doctor and infectious disease specialist, I’ve seen what does and doesn’t work It didn't have to be like this. We've known for years that the next great pandemic was going to come from a virus that leapt from animal to man. I wasn’t surprised when bats at a meat market in Wuhan, China were implicated in the latest scourge. It wasn’t a question of if but when. Nor am I surprised by the sluggish response we’ve seen from authorities around the world.Although the coronavirus’ suspected mortality rate of  2 per cent sounds low, it’s about the same as that of the Spanish flu of 1918 and that virus killed between 40 and 100 million people. To contain coronavirus, therefore, we must be vigilant, perform far more tests, and we must not cut corners.Before I became a doctor, I spent years studying the viruses that live in bats, everything from Ebola to rabies to Nipah Virus, because my research team suspected that bats were the linchpin for the next outbreak. We feared bats because they have a unique trait: the ability to suppress their immune system in the presence of an infection (this is thought to help cope with the stress of flying). It means bats can live with pathogens that kill humans.We knew to be fearful of these flying mammals. Around the time I became an infectious disease specialist in the United States, a federally-funded program called PREDICT was assembled to monitor infectious diseases in bats all over the world. Scientists used many of the techniques I helped to develop 15 years ago, gathering information that could be used to create vaccines, new medicines, and inform crucial public health decisions. PREDICT was shuttered in October, and I am unaware of any such programs operating elsewhere.It’s clear we took our eye off the ball. Now we're scrambling to catch up. But how? As the novel coronavirus sweeps the world - we're at more than 80,000 cases and counting - the virus has crept into 47 countries so far. Expect that number to rise. But where will it go next? A truism in epidemiology is that the more you look, the more you find, and many countries aren’t looking all that hard. The countries that have done the best job in containing the virus - Singapore among them, where recoveries are now outpacing new cases - were swift to ban inbound flights from China, quick to quarantine potential victims, and crucially, have conducted rigorous early testing.This is key. While leaders focus on quarantines, vaccines, and new medicines - all of which are important - we rarely hear about the development of new tests to detect deadly pathogens once an epidemic begins. This failure happens with every outbreak and it must change.China made major strategic mistakes at the onset. Once they identified a cluster of pneumonia associated with the meat market in Wuhan, they closed the market, citing “renovations”. Then, when they discovered how the virus was transmitted, they didn’t immediately reveal that it could be spread from one human to another. After eventually sharing this finding, they swung in the other direction and undertook a severe quarantine the largest in history. The World Health Organization initially said this was a mistake but eventually acknowledged the quarantine helped. The rest of the world needs to be proactive. Other countries must aggressively test people to indicate just how prolific this virus actually is. In Iran, of the 139 cases reported, 19 have died. This suggests we’re missing far too many patients, perhaps thousands.It's useful to take a look at how testing is done to understand why it’s failing in some countries. During any outbreak, the first step is for the government to quickly develop a new test (in this case, it took China about four weeks) then produce a lot of them. The testing relies on a form of nucleic acid amplification that’s rather straightforward once the virus has been sequenced. Private companies and academic laboratories can generally step in to manufacture them but must follow strict quality controls. This system usually works (in the US, it didn’t earlier this month the tests which the FDA sent to 50 states were found to be flawed and had to be recalled - which means we are very much in the dark as to the true scale of the spread there.)Things are looking more encouraging in the UK. The NHS has already tested more than 7,000 patients, 15 of which have so far been positive, and has now started piloting a home-testing scheme which means high-risk iniduals don’t have to leave self-isolation to undertake it. Select hospitals in the UK have been instructed to test a broad swathe of patients, including patients with flu-like symptoms who have no known link to a coronavirus case or travel to China, South Korea, or Italy. These are important steps they will hasten diagnosis, ensure patients are properly triaged, and will help contain this pandemic. Coronavirus is scary because there's so much uncertainty. We still don't know exactly where it came from, we don't know how long patients may remain asymptomatic after infection, and we don’t know where the virus is heading next. In many industrialised nations, including the United States, we still don't have the means to rapidly and efficiently diagnose coronavirus. As a result, the true extent of this pandemic remains a mystery. Some, including Harvard epidemiology professor Marc Lipsitch, predicts that by the end of the year, anywhere between 40 to 70 per cent of people will be infected with the virus globally - though this does not mean everyone will be severely ill as a result. We do not know how many people have only suffered mild symptoms and not sought medical treatment. Again, without proper diagnostics, we cannot understand the full scope of the problem. And downplaying the spread of a virus when it first hits is not the answer.Next time a bat passes one onto a human (and it will happen), we must get proper diagnostic testing up and running before we focus on anything else. It's a lesson we continue to relearn. Matt McCarthy is Assistant Professor of Medicine, Weill Cornell Medicine and the author of “Superbugs: The Race to Stop an Epidemic.”The  values your comments but kindly requests all posts are on topic, constructive and respectful. title: putting sixth form like putting sweetshop
story: To many pupils, David Wilkinson was a dazzlingly charismatic teacher. He had a first class brain and, rather like Robin Williams' character in Dead Poets Society, an uncanny ability to command pupils' attention.Colleagues admired how students excelled under his tuition, remembering him as the reason that a string of pupils from an ordinary Worcestershire school had gone on to study at Oxbridge.But while some students no doubt benefited from his academic attentions, others claim there was a high price to pay. Three of his former students have told The  he was a predator who used his position to groom female pupils for sex.They have decided to speak out now because they say the MeToo movement has helped them realise that what they had previously characterised as a relationship with an erudite older man was actually a wholly abusive breach of trust on his part.They hope it will embolden other women in similar positions to speak out about abusive former teachers.One alleged victim, Kerry, said: He would have sex with us or sexually assault us in his office on the school premises.She was just 15 when they first had intercourse, she claimed, saying: He saw me flirting with boys and he was concerned I was going to lose my virginity, so he wanted to get in there first.Mr Wilkinson told The  he did not acknowledge any of the alleged relationships. He said the allegations were turning into a nightmare for him, but that he had no further comment to make. I don't want to say anything … I have nothing to say about it. I'm sorry, he said.According to his alleged victims, the grooming would start with him putting stickers on their locker, playing footsie under the desk or inappropriately placing a hand on a knee at the theatre.They claimed he would hold private study groups at his house, offer students lifts home and invite his favourites to use his school office. Some of the alleged relationships would last for years, the women have said.One former student, who claimed she first had sex with Mr Wilkinson when she was 16, said: I would have a relationship with him as a boyfriend … it was always at his house. We never went anywhere else because it was a secret.After the relationship ended, she said, she put it in a box and never really dealt with it.The three women claimed he went to great lengths to keep the relationships secret. Kerry said he even encouraged her to move to a different school to ensure that he was safe.But he still engineered situations in which they would be alone together, she said. He is alleged to have sexually assaulted her in his school office. He also offered her private tuition to get her into Cambridge (which she eventually did), charging her parents for two-hour lessons that were largely spent in bed, she claimed.Kerry alleged that he seduced her by reciting poems about his lover's deep velvet amber eyes and her lips learning, yearning.She believed they were written for her, but said she later learnt she was not the only conquest to whom he recited them. He allegedly recycled the verses for another woman he started dating after she left school and would go on to marry and later orce.He also loved to discuss his favourite books, notorious pornographic novel 'The Story Of O' and 'Lolita', Vladimir Nabokov's infamous tale of a middle-aged professor who believes he is seduced by an underage child, Kerry said. They were his manuals for living, she added.Enthralled by him, she did everything he asked, and alleged their abusive relationship continued until she was 18, by which point, she said, they'd had sex hundreds and hundreds of times.Speaking from her home in Sydney, she described how he would ask her to pose for pornographic pictures and, she claimed, once borrowed a school video camera to film her naked. She was later humiliated to learn that his other lovers allegedly saw these pictures.But she was not the only one he was said to have slept with. He allegedly entered a sexual relationship with another student while he was abusing his position to have a relationship with Kerry.He was married to a fellow teacher, Susan Wilkinson, when he started teaching at the school. Ms Wilkinson left him after she became pregnant with his child, and he allegedly moved on to another colleague. Before the marriage disintegrated, one of the school's male teachers tried to warn Susan of Mr Wilkinson's behaviour, telling her that putting David in the sixth form is like putting him in a sweetshop.One other alleged victim recalled finding a trove of mementos: Polaroid photographs, letters and cards from girls who looked to be aged around 16. They were in their underwear – they weren't naked, but it was clear there was a sexual kind of scene to them, she said.Mr Wilkinson allegedly targeted very bright girls. The three who spoke to The  also admitted that they tended to come from difficult backgrounds. Some were still at school when the relationships began, they said. With others, Mr Wilkinson allegedly waited until after they completed their A-levels.According to the women, he would have sex with them at every opportunity.Kevin O'Regan, who became head teacher in 1997, after Mr Wilkinson retired, recalled some hearsay about an incident with a sixth-former that had taken place before 1985 but was told it had been dealt with.Mr Wilkinson was so adept at ensuring his behaviour was kept secret that head teachers in charge at the school for the near-quarter of a century he was there say they were entirely unaware of any alleged abuse.When approached by The , one former head said he remembered Mr Wilkinson as an excellent, brilliant teacher. He added: Nearly all the arts candidates who went to Oxbridge, and there were a number, were taught by him and he was the reason they got in. He was one of the best teachers I ever came across. Very able.What was startling about Mr Wilkinson's alleged campaign of abuse was the complexity of the web of deceit it would involve.One woman, Lucy, claimed Mr Wilkinson initiated their sexual relationship in his car after a party at his house to celebrate the end of A-levels. She later learned that he went home after their encounter and allegedly initiated a sexual relationship with another of her classmates.Lucy returned to the school the following year to re-sit some exams. He was displeased but they carried on their affair regardless, she said.She believed that formative experience set a pattern for many of her subsequent relationships. She – and every other former student The  spoke to – wept as she recounted the impact it had on her life.I'm not sure that our laws are sufficiently sophisticated at this point to understand the deep and profound ramifications of this kind of behaviour – that it is not only lifelong but also generational, she said. What's happened to me has also affected my children in ways that are very hard to describe.Like Kerry, she spent most of her life oblivious to the possibility that she might have been one of a string of girls to have become involved, and believed Mr Wilkinson had singled her out early on because she was somehow special.It was only in the wake of the MeToo movement that they started to reappraise things – and the discomfort they felt crystallised into horror.Kerry added: I think of him as almost evil – as a Svengali character who used his charisma and all of the tools at his disposal, literature and poetry, for sinister ends, to get what he wanted.And I think of him as being narcissistic. Up until this whole process, I think I was still somewhat grateful to him for what I had seen as a positive impact on my life, but I now realise that any positive impact was overstated and came at a huge, huge price to me.The allegations have been reported to the police. But the women's stories do not necessarily account for all those whose lives he allegedly affected.One girl who rejected his advances – whether wittingly or unwittingly – was allegedly subjected to a campaign of bullying by the man supposed to be nurturing her.Hillary Hinchliff, who went on to have a successful career in education and became principal of a renowned school in India, wept as she recounted how Mr Wilkinson made her life hell after she turned down his offer of a key to his private office.At the end of the day, he's a sick inidual who should have been stopped, she said.More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

And why does it matter?Stock markets in America and Europe have now entered official “correction” territory due to coronavirus fears.After a slight respite on Wednesday stock indexes across the world on Thursday continued their downward lurch as news emerged of more cases of Covid-19 infections outside China.&nbspWhy have coronavirus fears knocked $3 trillion off stock markets?Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesJapan announced today that it will shut every school in the country next Monday, affecting 13 million pupils, in order to contain the disease’s spread.But what does a stock market correction actually mean?And why does it matter to ordinary people?It’s simply where shares are trading more than 10 per cent below their recent peak in value.On Thursday afternoon both the S&ampP index of the 500 largest US companies and its (rough) European equivalent the STOXX 600 were down over 10 per cent on where they were a week ago.Because traders have woken up to the potential global&nbspeconomic impact of the Covid-19 outbreak.If growth stalls and company supply chains are disrupted by measures by governments to contain the virus that will be bad for company profits – and a hit to company profits translates into lower share prices.Nothing magical happens after a stock index falls by a tenth.But it’s a round number and that can be important in the psychology of traders.&nbspCreated with Sketch. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Trillions wiped off company values as governments prepare for pandemicStock markets across the world plummeted on Friday as analysts warned the deadly coronavirus outbreak could trigger a recession.Global stocks have seen an estimated $6 trillion wiped off their value in little over a month and there was no sign of the rout easing on Friday, with the FTSE 100 dropping 3 per cent immediately after opening. The UK's blue chip index of large companies briefly touched a three-and-a-half year low, before rallying to partially regain some of the day's losses.Among the biggest fallers was British Airways owner International Airlines Group which saw its shares tank after warning the Covid-19 had caused a drop in demand for flights. The carrier has now lost more than a quarter of its value in less than 10 days.&nbspSharing the full story, not just the headlinesAsian stock markets also plunged further on Friday after Wall Street registered its biggest single-day fall in nine years.In Tokyo, the Nikkei plummeted 3.7 per cent and markets in Seoul and Sydney dropped by more than 3 per cent. Hong Kong and Shanghai dropped by more than 2.5 per cent.Created with Sketch. That followed a bloodbath of a session in New York on Thursday which saw&nbspthe Dow Jones Industrial Average crashing 1,100 points.The S&ampP 500 sunk to its fastest-ever correction - meaning a fall of 10 per cent from a recent high -&nbspafter reaching the milestone in just six trading days.Connor Campbell, market analyst at Spreadex, said the historic falls would deepen when US&nbspmarkets open again on Friday.“The Dow Jones is facing a 500 point plunge when the bell rings on Wall Street, taking it below 25250 – more than 4000 points off of last week’s all-time highs.“Any market-rescuing positive headlines regarding the outbreak itself seem a way off.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. That’s lower activity, Mr Carney told Sky News.There’s less tourism - as you can see on our streets here in the UK. That’s lower activity as well.“We would expect world growth would be lower than it otherwise would be, and that has a knock-on effect on the UK.Oil prices also fell below $50 a barrel on the expectation that&nbspindustrial activity will slow down sharply.Companies that rely on tourism have been particularly badly hit as people call off trips. EasyJet's shares are down 27 per cent in a week that has seen some flights cancelled due to&nbspweaker demand. BA owner&nbspIAG announced strong 2019 figures but warned coronavirus would hurt profits this year.BA has suspended flights to mainland China - the epicentre of the outbreak - and has cut fits service to Hong Kong from two flights a day to one.A rapid rise in confirmed cases in Europe prompted the Swiss government to&nbspban events expected to attract more than 1,000 people. That means the car industry's most high-profile showcase&nbspmeeting, nect week's Geneva Motor Show, is set to be cancelled after Switzerland.The property industry's annual get-together in France,&nbspMIPIM, is going ahead this week but&nbspa number of companies have dropped out, citing concerns over coronavirus' spread.Consumer-facing companies such as retailers and restaurant owners are also expected to be negatively impacted as shoppers stay home.Firms in a host of sectors are also predicting they will be damaged by disruption to supply chains, many of which run through China.Primark owner Associated British Foods warned this week of shortages of some clothing lines if its factories in China remain disrupted for prolonged periods.A halt to production of iPhones in China forced Apple to announce that it did not expect to meet its second-quarter guidance but chief executive Tim Cook said on Thursday that factories supplying the tech company were beginning to reopen.“China is getting the coronavirus under control,” Mr Cook told Fox Business.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: coronavirus dean koontz eyes of darkness conspiracy wuhan china symptoms
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘The Eyes of Darkness’&nbspfeatures a conversation about a pandemic that hits a bit too close to home in 2020A 1981 novel by horror writer Dean Koontz&nbsppredicted the coronavirus outbreak, it has been claimed.Buried in the book&nbspThe Eyes of Darkness, which revolves around a&nbspgrieving mother investigating the mysterious circumstances of her son’s death,&nbspis a peculiar reference to a killer virus known as “Wuhan-400”, the name of the city where&nbspthe coronavirus originated.The excerpt features a character discussing biological warfare, calling the virus “the perfect weapon”.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“A Chinese scientist … defected to the United States, carrying a diskette record of China’s most important and dangerous new biological weapon in a decade,” the character says.Created with Sketch. Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.110 In Cold Blood by Truman Capote (1966)The first classic of the true crime genre was Capote’s investigation of the four murders that rocked the small farming community of Holcomb, Kansas. He spent six years fascinated with killers Richard Hickock and Perry Smith, after travelling to research the tragedy with his childhood friend Harper Lee. “No one will ever know what In Cold Blood took out of me,” Capote once said. “It scraped me right down to the marrow of my bones. It nearly killed me. I think, in a way, it did kill me.”210 I'll Be Gone in the Dark by Michelle McNamara (2018)In 2018, more than 50 rapes and 12 murders in California were finally matched to a single culprit after 40 years. It’s possible to argue the killer would have gone undiscovered forever if not for the extensive research left behind by journalist Michelle McNamara after her death in 2016, which became this portrait of obsession. A true crime enthusiast since childhood, she gave the Golden State Killer his catchy name and turned national attention back to his crimes. The most compelling passages show her holed up with evidence, compulsively re-reading the gory details. “There’s a scream permanently lodged in my throat now,” she writes at one point. 310 Happy Like Murderers by Gordon Burn (1998)Gordon Burn’s unflinching exploration of Fred and Rosemary West exposes the decay that lay at the heart of rural England. He shines a light on the brutality of the murderous couple’s backgrounds - not to make them sympathetic, but rather to show how a legacy of cruelty can curdle into violence.410 Helter Skelter by Vincent Bugliosi (1974)The best-selling true crime book of all time covers the infamous Manson murders, which have stayed in the public imagination now for 50 years. Buglioso, prosecutor in the Tate-LaBianca trials, lays out the events that inspired movies like 2019’s Oscar-winning Once Upon a Time in Hollywood. Buglioso resented attempts to turn the cult leader into a mystical folk hero. In this book, he instead exposed how Manson exploited people who were already susceptible to anti-social ideas. It remains our primary source of information on a murderous motive that combined white supremacy, drug-fuelled paranoia, and Beatles conspiracy theories.510 Party Monster by James St James (1999)James St James paints an indelible picture of New York nightlife in this infamous tale of drugs, sex, fashion and murder. The 1996 death of a drug dealer named Angel kicked off a scandalous series of events that rocked the city’s party scene. As a club kid himself, the author shows us how he became the confidant of one of the killers, and experienced the dark side of a subculture that embraced total anarchy.  Formerly titled Disco Bloodbath, the novel later became a feature film starring Macaulay Culkin. 610 The Journalist and the Murderer by Janet Malcolm (1999)This unusual story focuses more on the ethics of journalism than the violent crimes of its titular murderer, Jeffrey MacDonald. Journalist Joe McGinniss befriended the man, who had murdered his pregnant wife and two daughters, and then wrote a book based on everything MacDonald had told him.710 Unbelievable by T Christian Miller and Ken ArmstrongRecently adapted for a Netflix series starring Toni Collette, Merritt Wever, and Kaitlyn Dever, Miller and Armstrong’s story of a shocking rape investigation won them numerous awards, including the 2016 Pulitzer Prize. The book’s central crime took place in Lynnwood, Washington, in 2008, and justice wasn’t delivered until other cases emerged years later and 1,300 miles away in Colorado.810 Columbine by Dave Cullen (2009)Two decades later, the Columbine shootings are as sadly relevant as ever. Dave Cullen’s 2009 examination of the massacre shows how the media storm obscured the tragedy at the time, creating myths instead of soberly investigating the circumstances. Nuance and accuracy are key to the book’s success. Cullen pushes past the image we have of the two shooters to get to the truth.910 The Red Parts: Autobiography of a Trial by Maggie Nelson (2007)Maggie Nelson is known today for genre-defying critical successes like The Argonauts and Bluets, but this 2007 book about her aunt’s murder shows an early foray into true crime. The case had haunted her since childhood, and when new DNA evidence emerged to lay blame 35 years after the tragedy, Nelson observed the new suspect’s trial closely. Through the prism of her family’s grief, the book is beautifully lyrical at times. Her mother’s perspective is particularly crucial, as she mourns her younger sister’s short, turbulent life. Nelson remains rational and skeptical throughout, however, commenting on the nature of crime and punishment in enthralling prose. 1010 The Stranger Beside Me by Ann Rule (1980)Ann Rule aspired to be a crime novelist in the 1970s, but she couldn’t have known that her best-selling debut would be inspired by the man who worked next to her. 110 In Cold Blood by Truman Capote (1966)The first classic of the true crime genre was Capote’s investigation of the four murders that rocked the small farming community of Holcomb, Kansas. He spent six years fascinated with killers Richard Hickock and Perry Smith, after travelling to research the tragedy with his childhood friend Harper Lee. “No one will ever know what In Cold Blood took out of me,” Capote once said. “It scraped me right down to the marrow of my bones. It nearly killed me. I think, in a way, it did kill me.”210 I'll Be Gone in the Dark by Michelle McNamara (2018)In 2018, more than 50 rapes and 12 murders in California were finally matched to a single culprit after 40 years. It’s possible to argue the killer would have gone undiscovered forever if not for the extensive research left behind by journalist Michelle McNamara after her death in 2016, which became this portrait of obsession. A true crime enthusiast since childhood, she gave the Golden State Killer his catchy name and turned national attention back to his crimes. The most compelling passages show her holed up with evidence, compulsively re-reading the gory details. “There’s a scream permanently lodged in my throat now,” she writes at one point. 310 Happy Like Murderers by Gordon Burn (1998)Gordon Burn’s unflinching exploration of Fred and Rosemary West exposes the decay that lay at the heart of rural England. He shines a light on the brutality of the murderous couple’s backgrounds - not to make them sympathetic, but rather to show how a legacy of cruelty can curdle into violence.410 Helter Skelter by Vincent Bugliosi (1974)The best-selling true crime book of all time covers the infamous Manson murders, which have stayed in the public imagination now for 50 years. Buglioso, prosecutor in the Tate-LaBianca trials, lays out the events that inspired movies like 2019’s Oscar-winning Once Upon a Time in Hollywood. Buglioso resented attempts to turn the cult leader into a mystical folk hero. In this book, he instead exposed how Manson exploited people who were already susceptible to anti-social ideas. It remains our primary source of information on a murderous motive that combined white supremacy, drug-fuelled paranoia, and Beatles conspiracy theories.510 Party Monster by James St James (1999)James St James paints an indelible picture of New York nightlife in this infamous tale of drugs, sex, fashion and murder. The 1996 death of a drug dealer named Angel kicked off a scandalous series of events that rocked the city’s party scene. As a club kid himself, the author shows us how he became the confidant of one of the killers, and experienced the dark side of a subculture that embraced total anarchy.  Formerly titled Disco Bloodbath, the novel later became a feature film starring Macaulay Culkin. 610 The Journalist and the Murderer by Janet Malcolm (1999)This unusual story focuses more on the ethics of journalism than the violent crimes of its titular murderer, Jeffrey MacDonald. Journalist Joe McGinniss befriended the man, who had murdered his pregnant wife and two daughters, and then wrote a book based on everything MacDonald had told him.710 Unbelievable by T Christian Miller and Ken ArmstrongRecently adapted for a Netflix series starring Toni Collette, Merritt Wever, and Kaitlyn Dever, Miller and Armstrong’s story of a shocking rape investigation won them numerous awards, including the 2016 Pulitzer Prize. The book’s central crime took place in Lynnwood, Washington, in 2008, and justice wasn’t delivered until other cases emerged years later and 1,300 miles away in Colorado.810 Columbine by Dave Cullen (2009)Two decades later, the Columbine shootings are as sadly relevant as ever. Dave Cullen’s 2009 examination of the massacre shows how the media storm obscured the tragedy at the time, creating myths instead of soberly investigating the circumstances. Nuance and accuracy are key to the book’s success. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Trillions wiped off company values as governments prepare for pandemicStock markets across the world plummeted on Friday as analysts warned the deadly coronavirus outbreak could trigger a recession.Global stocks have seen an estimated $6 trillion wiped off their value in little over a month and there was no sign of the rout easing on Friday, with the FTSE 100 dropping 3 per cent immediately after opening. The UK's blue chip index of large companies briefly touched a three-and-a-half year low, before rallying to partially regain some of the day's losses.Among the biggest fallers was British Airways owner International Airlines Group which saw its shares tank after warning the Covid-19 had caused a drop in demand for flights. The carrier has now lost more than a quarter of its value in less than 10 days.&nbspSharing the full story, not just the headlinesAsian stock markets also plunged further on Friday after Wall Street registered its biggest single-day fall in nine years.In Tokyo, the Nikkei plummeted 3.7 per cent and markets in Seoul and Sydney dropped by more than 3 per cent. Hong Kong and Shanghai dropped by more than 2.5 per cent.Created with Sketch. That followed a bloodbath of a session in New York on Thursday which saw&nbspthe Dow Jones Industrial Average crashing 1,100 points.The S&ampP 500 sunk to its fastest-ever correction - meaning a fall of 10 per cent from a recent high -&nbspafter reaching the milestone in just six trading days.Connor Campbell, market analyst at Spreadex, said the historic falls would deepen when US&nbspmarkets open again on Friday.“The Dow Jones is facing a 500 point plunge when the bell rings on Wall Street, taking it below 25250 – more than 4000 points off of last week’s all-time highs.“Any market-rescuing positive headlines regarding the outbreak itself seem a way off.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailAnalysts warned that market turmoil offered a taste of the economic fall-out from a potential coronavirus pandemic.A worst case scenario of a global pandemic would undoubtedly have a significant economic impact and given the fragile nature of the global economy could tip the world into recession, said&nbspRichard Clode, portfolio manager at&nbspJanus Henderson.For now that remains a low probability outcome and our on the ground reports from an assortment of technology companies in China give us confidence that with the right measures in place the virus could potentially be contained.Wales confirms its first case of coronavirusChinese airlines sell flights for £3.20 amid coronavirus crisisCoronavirus: Switzerland bans all major public gatheringsDancing on Ice takes emergency precautions amid coronavirus fearsPeople think this 1981 horror novel predicted the coronavirus outbreakHalf of UK and US firms were already predicting a recession this year, according to a survey of 700 senior executives by trade finance provider Stenn.Bank of England Governor Mark Carney warned on Friday the Covid-19 outbreak could damage Britain’s economy as multinationals struggle to supply goods and services amid factory shutdowns and cancelled flights.What we are picking up with some of our bigger companies and companies around the world is that supply chains... are getting a little tight. That’s lower activity, Mr Carney told Sky News.There’s less tourism - as you can see on our streets here in the UK. That’s lower activity as well.“We would expect world growth would be lower than it otherwise would be, and that has a knock-on effect on the UK.Oil prices also fell below $50 a barrel on the expectation that&nbspindustrial activity will slow down sharply.Companies that rely on tourism have been particularly badly hit as people call off trips. EasyJet's shares are down 27 per cent in a week that has seen some flights cancelled due to&nbspweaker demand. BA owner&nbspIAG announced strong 2019 figures but warned coronavirus would hurt profits this year.BA has suspended flights to mainland China - the epicentre of the outbreak - and has cut fits service to Hong Kong from two flights a day to one.A rapid rise in confirmed cases in Europe prompted the Swiss government to&nbspban events expected to attract more than 1,000 people. That means the car industry's most high-profile showcase&nbspmeeting, nect week's Geneva Motor Show, is set to be cancelled after Switzerland.The property industry's annual get-together in France,&nbspMIPIM, is going ahead this week but&nbspa number of companies have dropped out, citing concerns over coronavirus' spread.Consumer-facing companies such as retailers and restaurant owners are also expected to be negatively impacted as shoppers stay home.Firms in a host of sectors are also predicting they will be damaged by disruption to supply chains, many of which run through China.Primark owner Associated British Foods warned this week of shortages of some clothing lines if its factories in China remain disrupted for prolonged periods.A halt to production of iPhones in China forced Apple to announce that it did not expect to meet its second-quarter guidance but chief executive Tim Cook said on Thursday that factories supplying the tech company were beginning to reopen.“China is getting the coronavirus under control,” Mr Cook told Fox Business.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet -
